description: From Middle French sensitif, from Medieval Latin sensitivus.

adjectives.description: sensitive (comparative more sensitive, superlative most sensitive)

entries.meaning: Having the faculty of sensation; pertaining to the senses.
(of a person) Easily offended, upset, or hurt.
examples: Max is very sensitive; he cried today because of the bad news.

entries.meaning: (of an issue, topic, etc.) Capable of offending, upsetting, or hurting.
examples: Religion is often a sensitive topic of discussion and should be avoided when dealing with foreign business associates.

entries.meaning: Meant to be concealed or kept secret.
Important, intricate, and requiring great delicacy.
examples: The president's untimely statement disrupted some very sensitive negotiations.

entries.meaning: (of an instrument) Accurate; able to register small changes in some property.
(archaic) Having paranormal abilities that can be controlled through mesmerism.
A person with a paranormal sensitivity to something that most cannot perceive.
examples: Swedenborg was one of the leading savants of Europe; it would be absurd to place any of our sensitives on the same intellectual level.
